sec.title: OBJECTIVE
sec.p: To develop and validate an instrument for measuring the home cooking skills of health professionals involved with guidelines for promoting adequate and healthy food in primary health care.

sec.title: METHODS
sec.p: This is a methodological study with a psychometric approach, carried out in the city of S√£o Paulo between January and November 2020, to develop and validate a self-applied online instrument. The data of the 472 participants were presented by descriptive statistics. Content validation was performed by expert judgment using the two round Delphi technique and empirical statistics for consensus evidence. Exploratory factor analysis was used for construct validation and reliability analysis, and the model adjustment rates and composite reliability were analyzed.

sec.title: RESULTS
sec.p: The instrument presented satisfactory content validity for CVRc indices and ùúÖ in the two rounds of the Delphi technique. After the factor analysis, the final model of the Primary Health Care Home Cooking Skills Scale presented 29 items with adequate factorial loads (> 0.3). Bartlett‚Äôs and Kaiser-Meyer-Olkin‚Äôs (KMO) tests of sphericity performed in exploratory factorial analysis suggested interpretability in the correlation matrix, the parallel analysis indicated four domains and explained variance of 64.1%. The composite reliability of the factors was adequate (> 0.70) and the H-index suggested replicable factors in future studies. All adjustment rates proved to be adequate.

sec.title: CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: The Primary Health Care Home Cooking Skills Scale presented evidence of validity and reliability. It is short and easy to apply and will make it possible to reliably ascertain the need for qualification of the workforce, favoring the planning of actions and public policies of promotion of adequate and healthy food in primary health care.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Home cooking skills (HCS) comprise actions such as menu planning, selection, mixing, cutting and cooking of food, the ability to perform tasks whilst cooking and confidence for culinary practices1. They are related to environmental and economic implications2 and are valued by the Guia Alimentar para a Popula√ß√£o Brasileira (Food Guidelines for the Brazilian Population)3 as an expression of cultural and social aspects. The document recognizes cooking as a strategic practice to promote adequate and healthy food (AHF), aiming to reduce the choice of ultra-processed foods, which are associated with overweight, obesity, cancer and other diseases4,5. Therefore, recognition of cooking should be paramount in food and nutrition education actions2.

In Brazil, the guidelines of AHF are located substantially within the scope of primary health care (PHC), the first level of care and link of subjects with the Unified Health System. PHC professionals play a relevant role in promoting food and nutrition education actions involving culinary practices, such as dissemination of recipes, workshops, guided visits to open-air markets, home visits and sensory exploration of food6. Such actions allow health workers to convey technical knowledge to the daily lives of the subjects, therefore it is important that those workers develop their home cooking skills7.

An accurate diagnosis of these skills is essential to promote workforce qualification and plan public health actions and policies on the subject, and it relies on the use of valid and reliable instruments, based on robust psychometric criteria8,9. Teixiera et al.10 identified and critically analyzed the psychometric quality of 12 Brazilian and international instruments for measuring cooking skills in adults. The psychometric attributes of those instruments were considered insufficient, with unsatisfactory results based on statistical criteria or methodological inadequacies. Two of the studies were Brazilian: Jomori11 performed a cross-cultural adaptation of an instrument based on the program Cooking with a Chef, from Clemson University. The results of a part of the scale of this instrument were unsatisfactory for reliability. Martins et al.12 developed a cooking confidence scale for parents of schoolchildren. The authors evaluated the internal consistency, stability and content validity of the instrument, but did not report agreement rates between experts and procedures for construct validity.

Thus, there is a strong need to develop a new instrument for assessing home cooking skills aimed at Brazilian health professionals involved with guidelines for promoting adequate and healthy food in PHC, based on psychometric criteria that follow methodological rigor to determine its validity and reliability recommended in the scientific literature.

sec.title: METHODS
sec.p: This is a methodological study with a psychometric approach13 conducted between January and November 2020.

This study was approved by the research ethics committee of University of S√£o Paulo (CAAE 15194819.8.0000.5421, No. 3,502,315) and by the co-participating institution of the S√£o Paulo Municipal Health Department (SMS-SP) (No. 3,585,369). The participants were informed of the objectives of the study and confidentiality of the data through an informed consent form.

In the prototype stage, a working group was created with nine members of both sexes and from different Brazilian states (S√£o Paulo, Mato Grosso, Par√° and Minas Gerais). They were nutrition and gastronomy majors from the Faculdade de Sa√∫de P√∫blica of Universidade de S√£o Paulo (FSP-USP) involved with culinary approach disciplines and PhD researchers with experience in the elaboration and validation of research instruments to systematically develop the instrument.

To define the theoretical domains and items of the first version of the instrument proposed in this study, the following were considered: (a) professional experience and culinary experience of the group; (b) exploration of theoretical framework on HCS14(c) systematic review to identify and analyze psychometric properties of instruments that assessed the home cooking skills of adults10. The domains, items and response formats of the instruments identified in this review were discussed by the research group for the construction of the prototype.

The construction of the initial set of items and response formats of the prototype version of the instrument, entitled Primary Health Care Home Cooking Skills Scale (PHCHCSS), followed the quality recommendations proposed by DeVellis15.

The next phase, the psychometric phase, consisted of three stages. The first stage featured experts from various professional levels, including university professors, researchers and nutrition and gastronomy professionals from Brazil16. A number of participants between three and 10 was considered sufficient17.

The two-round Delphi method 18 was used. Experts completed online questionnaires, with semi-structured questions of sociodemographic characterization and evaluation of the items and theoretical domains of the instrument built in the prototype phase. They proposed improvements, inclusion and exclusion of items, adequacy of the options of the instrument scale, and responded to a scale Likert of agreement (1 = strongly disagree and 4 = strongly agree) to evaluate each item for:

list-item.p: Clarity: Was the item written in such a way that the concept is understandable and adequately expresses what is to be measured?
Pertinence: Does the item reflect the concepts involved in the domain and is it adequate to achieve the proposed objectives?
Relevance: Is the item important for the construction of the domains that are the focus of the research scale?

sec.p: The first round of the panel took place between March 26 and April 29, 2020 and featured eight experts. The research group assessed the comments provided, excluded irrelevant and non-pertinent items, made adjustments to those considered unclear and included suggested items for a better coverage of the phenomenon. The instrument was re-submitted to the experts for evaluation after the modifications. Second round, started on May 28, 2020, lasted 30 days and featured seven experts.

The characteristics of the study participants were presented by descriptive statistics. The Critical Content Validity Ratio - CVRc was used to statistically analyze the validity of each attribute of the items and domains19and the Kappa coefficient (k) was calculated to evaluate the agreement between experts on each item20 of the two rounds of the panel. Items with CVRc > 0.05 and k ‚â• 0,6020 were retained19. The content validity index (CVI) was also used to analyze the validity of the instrument as a whole21. The result > 0.8 was considered acceptable22.

The second stage was the pre-test phase, in which professionals from a health center in the city of S√£o Paulo, with similar characteristics to the research population of the project, tested the usability of PHCHCSS. The pre-test participants were not part of the construct validity sample and reliability analysis of the instrument. They commented on possible difficulties in filling out the instrument, clarity and adequacy of the questions to the objective of the research and recorded response times.

In the third stage, construct validity and reliability of PHCHCSS were tested. The scale was developed for professionals involved in the promotion of adequate and healthy nutrition in basic health units (BHU) of S√£o Paulo‚Äôs Municipal Health Department (SMS-SP). There are 464 BHU in the city of S√£o Paulo23.

The sample included professionals who expressed their consent to participate. Recruitment was done by contacting regional health coordinators, technical health supervisors and BHU managers to collect the emails addresses of target professionals. A website was also developeda, advertised on social media to present and clarify the purpose of the research and to recruit participants. The number of participants in the sample was based on the recommendations of Costello and Osborne24, of 10 subjects per instrument item.

Data collection began on August 2, 2020, lasting 30 days. A total of 472 professionals answered a sociodemographic questionnaire and PHCHCSS online. Their characteristics were presented by descriptive statistics.

Exploratory factor analysis (EFA) was used to evaluate the factorial structure of the PHCHCSS. Polychoric correlation and the Robust Diagonally Weighted Least Squares (RDWLS) extraction method were used. The decision on the number of retained factors was made by parallel analysis with random permutation of the observed data25. The rotation used was the Robust Promin26. Values of 60% of the total variance explained, items with commonality ‚â• 0.4 and factorial loads ‚â• 0.30 were considered satisfactory. Items with cross-factorial loads were excluded27. KMO values ‚â• 0.70 and significant values for Bartlett‚Äôs index represented adequacy measures of the sample28.

The goodness of fit of the model was evaluated using the Root Mean Square Error of approximation (RMSEA) index, the Comparative Fit Index (CFI) and the Tucker-Lewis Index (TLI). RMSEA values should be < 0.08, and CFI and TLI values should be > 0.90 or, preferably, 0.9529,30.

The stability of the factors was assessed by the H-index, which assesses how well a set of items represents a factor. H values > 0.80 suggest a well-defined and probably stable latent variable in different studies31.
To test the reliability, the composite reliability (CR) was calculated, with acceptable values > 0.7032.
All statistical analyses were performed using the statistical software Factor, version 10.10.0329.

sec.title: RESULTS
sec.p: The Box presents details on the theoretical domains and the construction of a set of items of the prototype version of the PHCHCSS based on the discussions of the research group, exploration of the theoretical framework and systematic review. Forty-four items were proposed to evaluate the home cooking skills of PHC professionals, with response options structured into a five-point Likert-type scale (0 = strongly disagree and 5 = strongly agree).

caption.title: Identification of theoretical domains and construction of a set of items of the prototype version of the PHCHCSS.

sec.p: The instruments identified in a systematic review had dimensions of planning, selection and purchase of food and confidence in food preparation, and may or may not include pre-prepared and convenience products.

For the PHCHCSS, the theoretical dimensions of HCS for the construction of the initial items were considered to be the food shopping planning and meal preparation, culinary creativity, the use of sensory perception and confidence in the preparation of meals based on fresh, minimally processed and culinary ingredients, as recommended by the Guia Alimentar para a Popula√ß√£o Brasileira. Multitasking skills were also identified as a theoretical domain. They are defined in the scientific literature as the ability to perform tasks simultaneously in the home environment, representing an advantage when preparing meals.
The prototype version of the instrument was submitted to content evaluation by experts. The main results of the development and validation of the PHCHCSS are shown in the Figure.

fig.label: Figure

caption.title: Flowchart of the development process of the items and domains of the instrument.

fig.attrib: PHCHCSS: Primary Health Care Home Cooking Skills Scale; PHC: primary health care.

sec.p: In the psychometric phase, the first stage was the validation of the content. The study sample size was adequate for this stage. The response rate for the first round of the Delphi technique was 72.7% (8/11) and 87.5% (7/8) for the second round. Most of the experts were female (n = 7; 87.5%), with a mean age of 42.3 years (SD = 9.0). Of the total, 37.5% (n = 3) were experts (latu sensu), 12.5% (n = 1) masters, 25% (n = 2) PhDs and 12.5% (n = 1) full professors. The panel also had a lay participant (n = 1; 12.5%) with training in gastronomy and a full-time job cooking. The experts were professors at public (25%) and private (12.5%) universities, researchers (12.5%), nutritionists in food services (37.5%) and culinary professionals (12.5%). The length of professional experience ranged from 10 to 33 years (mean = 17.8 years; SD = 7.9 years). The average time devoted to culinary practices among experts was 12.2 hours per week (SD = 9.6 hours per week).

The evaluation of the experts resulted in the exclusion of seven items from the prototype version of the instrument, two items transferred from their original domains, three items revised for clarity, six new items proposed and a change from the agreement scale to a frequency scale, totaling 43 valid items for content. An overview of the content validity analysis of the instrument is shown in Table 1.

caption.title: Content validity analysis of the Primary Health Care Home Cooking Skills by experts.

tr.td: Domain 1. Shopping planning and meal preparation When planning my shopping and meals, I satisfactorily perform the following tasks:
Research the harvest year when buying fruits, vegetables and legumes
Make a shopping list before going to the supermarket
Research food prices before buying them
Organize myself to prepare the meals I will consume throughout the week
Freeze prepared meals in batches to reduce time in the kitchen
Domain 2. Cooking creativity I consider myself creative enough to:
Cook different preparations from the same ingredients
Use leftovers to prepare a new meal
Use unconventional parts of food (e.g., leaves, skin, stalks, seeds) to prepare recipes
Domain 3. Preparation and multitasking skills I believe that I have enough skills to:
Blanch broccoli florets, applying heat shock for the appropriate time
Briefly soak beans in hot water, discarding the water after 1 hour
Chop an onion properly into small cubes
Prepare vegetable stock from fresh ingredients
Check if a cake has finished baking with a wooden stick
Thicken starch-based preparations without forming lumps
Measure the correct amount of water to prepare fluffly rice
Quickly desalt dried meat in boiling water
Correct the acidity of sauces using in natura ingredients, like carrots
Tenderize tough meats, like beef shank, by stewing
Prepare a homemade feijoada from scratch
Fry potatoes properly, without making them greasy
Cook while doing other household chores (e.g., laundry, house cleaning)
Attend to a matter over the phone while cooking pasta
Prepare a main meal (lunch/dinner) in less than 30 minutes
Domain 4. Sensory perception I consider my sensory perceptions suitable to:
Replace fresh herbs with dried herbs in cooking preparations by using only my sensory perceptions
Dose the amount of spices when experimenting with food during preparation
Combining foods based on previous cooking experiences
Judge that a meal based on pasta with tomato sauce, watermelon juice and strawberry jelly has inadequate visual appeal
Differentiate sauces prepared with industrialized vegetable stock from those prepared with natural ingredients by using only my palate
Identify the doneness of grilled meat (rare, medium, well done) by using only my perceptions of texture. (e.g., by pressing it with a spatula)
Know when the flour used to prepare a white sauce is cooked properly by using only the sense of smell (to identify the almond aroma)
Domain 5. Confidence I am confident enough to:
Prepare a caramel sauce for a flan
Follow a recipe from start to finish
Grill meat to the desired doneness
Adjust the amount of ingredients in a recipe for a larger number of people
Convert universal measurements (gram, kilogram, liter) into homemade measurements (spoonful, glass, cup)
Bake a simple cake without a recipe
Handle unexpected situations when cooking (e.g., turning overwhipped cream into butter)
Domain 1. Shopping planning and meal preparation I perform the following actions:
Consider the harvest year when buying fruits, vegetables and legumes
Make a list before I go shopping
Consider food prices before buying it
Organize my time to produce the meals I will consume throughout the week
Freeze prepared meals in batches to consume on other days
Plan the menu considering the use of unconventional parts of food (e.g., skins, stalks, seeds)
Decide the amount of food to be bought based on the number of people eating at homef
Plan the meals I will consume taking into account the variety of foods (e.g., vegetables, legumes, meats, grains)f
Check the items I have at home before buying foodf
Domain 2. Cooking creativity I use my creativity to:
Prepare different recipes from the same ingredients
Create different sauces to vary meals
Use leftovers from previous meals to prepare a new recipe
Adapt recipes with the ingredients I have at homef
Handle unexpected situations when I‚Äôm cooking (e.g., preparing a soup with overcooked beans)f
Domain 3. Preparation and multitasking skills I perform the following actions:
Prepare stocks from ingredients in natura (e.g., fresh vegetables, meat trimmings) to impart flavor to culinary preparations
Recognize when a cake is fully baked
Thicken cooking preparations with cornstarch without forming lumps
Use the correct amount of water to prepare fluffy rice
Correct the acidity of sauces using in natura ingredients, like carrots
Cook tough meats, such as beef shank, in liquid to make them softer
Fry food without making it greasy
Do other household chores (e.g., laundry, house cleaning) while cooking
Attend to a matter on the phone while the pots are on the heat
Prepare lunch / dinner from scratch in less than 30 minutes
Discard the water in which the beans soaked before cooking them
Domain 4. Sensory perception I use my sensory perceptions to:
Replacing fresh herbs with dried herbs in culinary preparations by using only my sensory perceptions
Adjust the amount of seasonings when tasting food during preparation
Combine foods based on their taste
Differentiate sauces prepared with industrialized vegetable stock from those prepared with natural ingredients by using only my palate
Identify how cooked food is according to its consistency (e.g., hard, soft, mushy)
Recognize that a white sauce is ready according to its thick texture
Identify whether foods are suitable for consumption based on their sensory characteristics (e.g., red color of strawberries, soft texture of avocados, sour smell of spoiled food)
Domain 5. Confidence I feel confident to:
Follow a cooking recipe from start to finish
Cook food according as instructed in a recipe (e.g., firm beans for a salad, medium meats)
Adjust the amount of ingredients in a recipe for a larger number of people
Convert universal measurements (e.g., gram, kilo, litre) to home measurements (e.g., spoonful, glass, cup)
Bake a simple cake without instructions

fn.p: CVI: content validity index.
a Round 1: CVRc: 8 experts = p = 0.05 = 0.693; Round 2: CVRc: 7 experts = p = 0.05 = 0.74119.
b The Kappa (k) coefficient for agreement among experts was performed with the help of the calculator available at: http://justusrandolph.net/kappa/.

c Initial response scale of the instrument corresponded to the Likert type for agreement, as follows: (1) Strongly disagree, (2) disagree, (3) Neither agree nor disagree, (4) Agree, (5) Strongly agree. This response scale was changed to a frequency scale at the suggestion of the experts after Round 1. Experts reported that the respondents found it difficult to understand the agreement scales. In addition, agreement scales can indicate the individual‚Äôs perception of their skills, but they do not necessarily reflect the behaviors that make it possible to actually measure such skills. In this case, the adequacy for a frequency scale was shown to be more consistent with the objective of this instrument. The amendment was approved by the experts who took part in Round 2. The new scale is presented as follows: (1) Never, (2) Almost Never, (3) Sometimes, (4) Almost always, (5) Always. The authors made minimal changes to the labels and questions of the instrument (without changing their objectives) to make them coherent with the new response scale. Those changes were also approved by the experts.

d Items excluded by the researchers with the consent of the expert group after consultation in the second stage of the panel. The item Buy food at food markets was excluded considering that one can shop for food in other places, not only food markets, and that this subject was included in other items of the instrument; item Quickly desalt dried meat in boiling water was excluded considering that the purpose of the instrument is to measure the cooking skills for preparing daily meals (dried meat is not consumed on a daily basis in the city of S√£o Paulo) and, considering the frequency label, there could be an interpretation bias on the part of respondents (respondents could inform the frequency with which they prepare dried meat without desalting it); Prepare homemade feijoada from the scratch was excluded considering that the purpose of the instrument is to measure cooking skills for preparing everyday meals (feijoada, though a typical Brazilian dish, is not prepared every day in the city of S√£o Paulo) and, considering the frequency label, there could be an interpretation bias on the part of respondent (respondents could inform the frequency with which they cook feijoada and not if they make it from scratch).

e Justification not presented by the expert or not accepted by the author. Although the CVRc were slightly lower than the critical reference limit for the relevance attribute19, the item was kept in view of the value of agreement among experts on the item and to ensure the coverage of the domain. We chose to keep the item and investigate its behavior in factor analysis.

f New items, submitted to content validity analysis (clarity, pertinence, relevance and agreement among experts) in the second Round of the panel of experts. The themes included in the added items comprised suggestions from experts in the first Round, to expand the scope of the domains.

sec.p: The second stage, pre-test, was conducted by five professionals from a health center in the city of S√£o Paulo. The covid-19 pandemic posed an obstacle for recruitment, given the intensified demand for care at BHU. The sample was composed of women who worked as nutritionists (n = 3; 60%), psychologists (n = 1, 20%) and nurses (n = 1; 20%). This sample was not part of the validity and reliability analysis of the instrument. Participants reported that the instrument was easy to access by computer, comprehension of the questions and answer options, with a suggestion to enlarge the font size of the questions, which was adopted by the research group. The average response time was 15 minutes.

The third stage consisted in performing construct validity and reliability analysis. The study sample size was adequate for this stage. Table 2 shows the characteristics of the 472 health professionals from the participating PHC.

sec.p: The EFA was initially performed with a version of the instrument validated by experts, with 43 items. Bartlett‚Äôs (5.248; gl = 903; p < 0.001) and KMO (0.91: very good) test of sphericity suggested interpretability of the correlation matrix. The parallel analysis suggested four representative factors for the data, with an explained variance of 54.6%. Some items had insignificant factorial loads and commonalities25. After these items were excluded, the instrument was analyzed again. Subsequently, items with cross-factorial loads in the interpretation of factors were removed and the instrument underwent a new analysis. The reduced model of the instrument retained 29 of the 43 items. Bartlett‚Äôs (5.301,7; gl = 406; p < 0.001) and KMO (0.91: very good) test of sphericity suggested interpretability of the correlation matrix, with four factors identified in the parallel analysis and explained variance of 64.1%.

The final EHAPS model resulted in a scale of the type Likert, with response options on the frequency of actions centered on HCD attributes, with 29 itemsb. The scale score is determined by the sum of the scores corresponding to the options indicated in each item (‚Äúnever‚Äù = 0, ‚Äúalmost never‚Äù = 1, ‚Äúsometimes‚Äù = 2, ‚Äúalmost always‚Äù = 3 and ‚Äúalways‚Äù = 4). Based on the sum of points of the items, four score ranges were proposed with the following statuses: low HCS (0 to 29 points, equivalent to ‚â§ 25% of the maximum score); moderately low HCS (30 to 58 points, equivalent to > 25% and ‚â§ 50% of the maximum score); moderately high HCS (59 to 87 points, corresponding to > 50% and ‚â§ 75% of the maximum score) and high HCS (88 to 116 points, or > 75% of the maximum score). The interpretation of the final score was graphically presented in a ruler format with color gradation (from intense red, representing low HCS, to intense green, representing high HCS), with instructional messages about the score achieved and encouragement to the development of these skills.

Table 3 shows the sequence of item reduction by EFA. The factorial loads of the retained items, composite reliability indexes and replicability estimates of the factor scores (H-index) are shown in Table 4. Names and descriptions of the construct measured by each factor extracted in the EFA are also reported based on the interpretation of the items retained. These factors were understood as dimensions of home cooking skills assessed by the PHCHCSS.

caption.title: Sequence of item reduction by exploratory factor analysis of the Primary Health Care Home Cooking Skills Scale.

sec.p: The items retained showed adequate loads in their respective factors. No new patterns of cross loads were found in the reduced model (i.e. items with factorial loads > 0.30 in more than one factor). The composite reliability of the factors was adequate (> 0.70) for all factors. The H-index measure suggested replicable factors in future studies (H > 0.80)28.
It should be noted that the factorial structure presented adequate adjustment indexes (œá2 = 296, gl = 334,246; p = 0.06; RMSEA = 0.037; IFC = 0.99; TLI = 0.99).

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: This study reported the development of an instrument to measure the home cooking skills of primary health care professionals in the city of S√£o Paulo. The psychometric methodology proved to be appropriate to analyze the reliability and validity of the PHCHCSS.

Although uncommon in scale development studies, the content validity stage had a lay member in the the expert panel33. The inclusion of this member allowed identifying and correcting potential problems in the scale in advance of its application for data collection for exploratory factor analysis8. The application of the strict consensus method with two measures (CVRc and k) to quantify the degree of agreement among experts resulted in items with strong content validity. The opinion of experts was considered in other studies that reported instruments for measuring cooking skills12,34. However, these studies did not present empirical methods derived from the judgment of experts as evidence of the content validity. The fact that experts give opinions on construct items does not in itself provide relevant information for the validation process13,28. Thus, this study stands out regarding the methodological rigor employed for content validity of the PHCHCSS.

The pre-test participants reported adequate usability of the instrument. Five health professionals participated in this stage. Rattray et al.35 assert that pilot studies can be conducted with small samples as long as the performance of the analyses is not compromised in any way. Considering that the sample was used to qualitatively evaluate the understanding and deployment of the instrument, the number of pre-test professionals did not create limitations to the study.

Regarding the stage of construct validity and reliability of the PHCHCSS, the parallel analysis suggested a multidimensional instrument with four factors. The multidimensionality of the scale is aligned with the complex nature of the acts of eating and cooking, recognized by the Guia Alimentar para a Popula√ß√£o Brasileira3.

The creative planning dimension considers creativity when planning and preparing home-cooked meals in natura, minimally processed foods and procedures done in advance to facilitate the act of cooking. A similar finding was observed in the study by Jomori11, which considers the creative ability to plan menus and organize meal preparation as skills for individual-centered culinary practice. This dimension is related to the main recommendation of the Guia Alimentar para a Popula√ß√£o Brasileira3: ‚ÄúYou should always prefer in natura or minimally processed foods and culinary preparations to ultra-processed foods‚Äù. It is also related to the chapter on understanding and overcoming obstacles to putting this and other recommendations into practice. Cooking procedures done in advance shorten the time spent preparing meals. Given the pace of modern life, this obstacle is more easily overcome when multitasking skills are also put into practice.

The dimension of multitasking skills comprises the ability to perform household tasks simultaneously to culinary practices. If an individual is unable to cook while doing laundry and taking care of children, they may be less likely to prepare a home-cooked meal36. Gabe37 discusses the influence of the home environment on the quality of the meals consumed, highlighting that there is a gender discrepancy regarding responsibility for household chores, which is reinforced by Mills et al.38 These findings provide an opportunity to use the PHCHCSS in studies aimed at analyzing differences in multitasking skills between genders, in order to encourage the fair sharing of responsibilities in the home, which includes preparing meals.

The dimension of confidence regarding cooking skills corresponds to self-sufficiency to employ cooking techniques and utensils. According to Martins12, the confidence judgment considers individual performance, which depends on practice and task performed, considered an excellent predictor of behavior to determine how individuals employ their skills. The PHCHCSS reduces misinterpretations about HCS by disregarding questions about confidence to prepare meals based on ready-made and convenience products, which could overestimate the individual‚Äôs skills, a recurring problem in international instruments1. The cooking confidence scale by Lavelle et al.34, for example, includes questions about confidence to ‚Äúprepare food in a microwave oven, including heating ready-made dishes‚Äù.

Finally, the dimension of food selection, combination and preparation refers to the sensory and quantification aspects of food aiming at the adequacy of purchasing and cooking procedures. Similar components, which concern the ability to shop for food, use it in preparations and judge it for quality, are found in the study about food literacy by Vidgen and Gallegos39. According to the authors, low food literacy is associated with increased diet-related chronic diseases.

The results of the exploratory factor analysis showed adequate factorial loads and commonalities in all items retained in the instrument27,28and they suggest a well-defined latent variable, with dimensions that are likely to be stable in future studies31. The adjustment indexes presented validated the model extracted from the analysis and confirm the measured theory, showing a well-defined construct30. The reliability of the instrument was also adequate, with satisfactory results of composite reliability. This measure represents a good indicator to evaluate the quality of the structural model of the instrument and is presented as a more robust precision indicator, compared to the alpha coefficient32.
Developing evaluation instruments is a complex task, only recommended in the lack of another instrument suitable to the reality being investigated40, which is the case in this study.

As an advantage, the PHCHCSS is short, easy to apply and standardized, allowing its use in comparative studies. This instrument summarizes the home cooking skills according to scoreranges easy to interpret, delimited by traffic light colors, based on a diagram suggested by Gabe37 to interpret the score of her dietary quality assessment instrument, adopted by the Ministry of Health. It also offers messages on the status of the individual‚Äôs home cooking skills, with instructions for encouraging and appreciating these skills. It should be noted, however, that the score of the scale derives from its raw score. Although commonly found in studies of instrument development, the use of this score assumes a subjective definition of classification cut-off points, conferring the same weight for items with different factorial loads. The item response theory is an analysis proposal to overcome this limitation by considering the characteristics of the questionnaire items regarding the ability to differentiate the variable of interest and location in the respective continuum and a probabilistic model to estimate and describe the scores41. Thus, the item response theory could be used in future studies aiming to improve the score of this instrument, validated by classical methods.

Automation minimized possible errors by the interviewer. The online application of the instrument proved advantageous due to its low cost and ease of access. However, its application on paper has not been studied to verify the occurrence of similar results, a limitation of this study. The printed version would allow access to health professionals working in places with limited internet access or not included digitally.

Another limitation is that a convergent validity study was not conducted. This kind of validity refers to the associations of the PHCHCSS score with external measures, which could confirm whether the scale measures HCS related to food choices recommended by the Guia Alimentar para a Popula√ß√£o Brasileira and could be performed by comparing the scale score with a 24-hour dietary recall or with the score of a food literacy scale. Conducting this validity study would be opportune in future analyses.

Finally, the sample used for exploratory factor analysis was composed of professionals working in primary health care in the city of S√£o Paulo. Despite being the main destination for regional migration in Brazil42, the sample from this city may not represent the cultural diversity of food within the national territory. Thus, a cross-cultural adaptation of the instrument for Brazilian macroregions is recommended.

This study is innovative in the context of the recognition of cooking as an emancipatory practice and health promotion. It is understood mastering home cooking skills allows primary health care professionals to bring their scientific knowledge closer to people‚Äôs lives and to social practices and knowledge, thereby strengthening the ability of individuals or communities to identify solutions for their daily lives. This instrument will make it possible to reliably ascertain the need for qualification of the workforce for actions to promote healthy and adequate food based on home cooking skills. It also provides opportunities to identify needs for reviewing pedagogical proposals of health courses, to train professionals to work on food sovereignty and the human right to adequate food at the expense of medicalizing practices and guidelines.

sec.title: OBJETIVO
sec.p: Desenvolver e validar instrumento para mensura√ß√£o de habilidades culin√°rias dom√©sticas de profissionais de sa√∫de envolvidos com orienta√ß√µes de promo√ß√£o da alimenta√ß√£o adequada e saud√°vel da aten√ß√£o prim√°ria √† sa√∫de.

sec.title: M√âTODOS
sec.p: Estudo metodol√≥gico com abordagem psicom√©trica, realizado no munic√≠pio de S√£o Paulo entre janeiro e novembro de 2020, para desenvolvimento e valida√ß√£o de instrumento on-line autoaplic√°vel. Os dados dos 472 participantes foram apresentados por estat√≠stica descritiva. A valida√ß√£o de conte√∫do foi realizada por julgamento de especialistas utilizando t√©cnica Delphi de dois rounds e estat√≠sticas emp√≠ricas para evid√™ncia de consenso. Empregou-se an√°lise fatorial explorat√≥ria para valida√ß√£o de constructo e an√°lise de confiabilidade, analisados √≠ndices de ajuste do modelo e fidedignidade composta.

sec.title: RESULTADOS
sec.p: O instrumento apresentou validade de conte√∫do satisfat√≥ria para √≠ndices de CVRc e ùúÖ nos dois rounds da t√©cnica Delphi. Ap√≥s an√°lise fatorial, o modelo final da Escala de Habilidades Culin√°rias Dom√©sticas da Aten√ß√£o Prim√°ria √† Sa√∫de apresentou 29 itens com cargas fatoriais adequadas (> 0,3). Os testes de esfericidade de Bartlett e Kaiser-Meyer-Olkin (KMO) realizados em an√°lise fatorial explorat√≥ria sugeriram interpretabilidade na matriz de correla√ß√£o, a an√°lise paralela indicou quatro dom√≠nios e vari√¢ncia explicada de 64,1%. A fidedignidade composta dos fatores foi adequada (> 0,70) e o √≠ndice H sugeriu fatores replic√°veis em estudos futuros. Todos os √≠ndices de ajustes mostraram-se adequados.

sec.title: CONCLUS√ïES
sec.p: A Escala de Habilidades Culin√°rias Dom√©sticas da Aten√ß√£o Prim√°ria √† Sa√∫de apresentou evid√™ncias de validade e confiabilidade. √â curta e de f√°cil aplica√ß√£o e possibilitar√° a averigua√ß√£o de forma fidedigna da necessidade de qualifica√ß√£o da for√ßa de trabalho, favorecendo o planejamento de a√ß√µes e pol√≠ticas p√∫blicas de promo√ß√£o da alimenta√ß√£o adequada e saud√°vel na aten√ß√£o prim√°ria √† sa√∫de.

sec.title: INTRODU√á√ÉO
sec.p: As habilidades culin√°rias dom√©sticas (HCD) compreendem a√ß√µes de planejamento do card√°pio, sele√ß√£o, combina√ß√£o, corte e coc√ß√£o dos alimentos, capacidade de realizar tarefas concomitantes ao ato de cozinhar e confian√ßa para pr√°ticas culin√°rias1. Est√£o relacionadas √†s implica√ß√µes ambientais e econ√¥micas2 e s√£o valorizadas pelo Guia Alimentar para a Popula√ß√£o Brasileira3 como express√£o de aspectos culturais e sociais. O documento reconhece a culin√°ria como pr√°tica estrat√©gica para promo√ß√£o da alimenta√ß√£o adequada e saud√°vel (PAAS), visando reduzir a escolha de alimentos ultraprocessados, cujo consumo se associa ao sobrepeso, obesidade, c√¢ncer e outras doen√ßas4,5. Logo, a valoriza√ß√£o do ato de cozinhar deve ser central nas a√ß√µes de educa√ß√£o alimentar e nutricional2.

No Brasil, as orienta√ß√µes de PAAS ocorrem substancialmente no √¢mbito da aten√ß√£o prim√°ria √† sa√∫de (APS), o primeiro n√≠vel de aten√ß√£o e v√≠nculo dos sujeitos de direito com o Sistema √önico de Sa√∫de. Profissionais da APS desempenham relevante papel ao promover a√ß√µes de educa√ß√£o alimentar e nutricional que envolvem pr√°ticas culin√°rias, como divulga√ß√£o de receitas, oficinas, visitas guiadas a feiras livres, visitas domiciliares e explora√ß√£o sensorial de alimentos6. Tais a√ß√µes possibilitam ao profissional de sa√∫de articular conhecimentos t√©cnicos ao cotidiano dos sujeitos, portanto, √© importante que esse profissional se aproprie das habilidades culin√°rias dom√©sticas7.

O diagn√≥stico preciso dessas habilidades √© essencial para promover qualifica√ß√£o da for√ßa de trabalho e planejar a√ß√µes e pol√≠ticas p√∫blicas de sa√∫de sobre a tem√°tica e depende do emprego de instrumentos v√°lidos e confi√°veis, baseados em crit√©rios psicom√©tricos robustos8,9. Teixeira et al.10 identificaram e analisaram criticamente a qualidade psicom√©trica de 12 instrumentos brasileiros e internacionais que mensuram habilidades culin√°rias em adultos, cujos atributos psicom√©tricos foram considerados insuficientes, com resultados insatisfat√≥rios frente aos crit√©rios estat√≠sticos ou inadequa√ß√µes metodol√≥gicas. Dois dos estudos eram brasileiros: Jomori11 realizou adapta√ß√£o transcultural de um instrumento baseado no programa Cooking with a Chef, da Universidade de Clemson, cujos resultados de confiabilidade de parte da escala foram insatisfat√≥rios. Martins et al.12 desenvolveram uma escala de confian√ßa culin√°ria para pais de crian√ßas em idade escolar. Os autores avaliaram consist√™ncia interna, estabilidade e validade de conte√∫do do instrumento, por√©m n√£o reportaram √≠ndices de concord√¢ncia entre especialistas e procedimentos para validade de constructo.

Fortaleceu-se, assim, a necessidade de desenvolver um novo instrumento de avalia√ß√£o das habilidades culin√°rias dom√©sticas, destinado aos profissionais de sa√∫de brasileiros que atuam pela PAAS no contexto da APS, com base em crit√©rios psicom√©tricos que respeitem rigor metodol√≥gico para determina√ß√£o de sua validade e confiabilidade recomendados em literatura cient√≠fica.

sec.title: M√âTODOS
sec.p: Estudo metodol√≥gico com abordagem psicom√©trica13, realizado entre janeiro e novembro de 2020.

Este estudo foi aprovado pelo comit√™ de √©tica em pesquisa da Universidade de S√£o Paulo (CAAE 15194819.8.0000.5421, no. 3.502.315) e pela institui√ß√£o coparticipante da Secretaria Municipal de Sa√∫de de S√£o Paulo (SMS-SP) (no. 3.585.369). Os participantes foram informados dos objetivos do estudo e sigilo dos dados por meio de termo de consentimento livre e esclarecido.

Na fase protot√≠pica criou-se um grupo de trabalho com nove integrantes de ambos os sexos e de diferentes estados brasileiros (S√£o Paulo, Mato Grosso, Par√° e Minas Gerais) com forma√ß√£o em nutri√ß√£o e gastronomia, acad√™micos da Faculdade de Sa√∫de P√∫blica da Universidade de S√£o Paulo (FSP-USP) envolvidos com disciplinas de abordagem culin√°ria e pesquisadores de doutorado com experi√™ncia em elabora√ß√£o e valida√ß√£o de instrumentos de pesquisa para desenvolver sistematicamente o instrumento.

Para a defini√ß√£o dos dom√≠nios te√≥ricos e itens da primeira vers√£o do instrumento proposto neste estudo, considerou-se: (a) viv√™ncia profissional e experi√™ncia culin√°ria do grupo; (b) explora√ß√£o de referencial te√≥rico sobre HCD14; (c) revis√£o sistem√°tica para identificar e analisar propriedades psicom√©tricas de instrumentos que avaliaram as habilidades culin√°rias dom√©sticas de adultos10. Os dom√≠nios, itens e formatos de resposta dos instrumentos identificados nesta revis√£o foram discutidos pelo grupo de pesquisa para a constru√ß√£o do prot√≥tipo.

A constru√ß√£o do conjunto inicial de itens e formatos de resposta da vers√£o protot√≠pica do instrumento, intitulado Escala de Habilidades Culin√°rias Dom√©sticas da Aten√ß√£o Prim√°ria √† Sa√∫de (EHAPS), seguiu as recomenda√ß√µes de qualidade propostas por DeVellis15.

A fase seguinte, a psicom√©trica, foi constitu√≠da por tr√™s etapas. A primeira etapa contou com a participa√ß√£o de especialistas de diversos n√≠veis profissionais, entre docentes universit√°rios, pesquisadores e profissionais de nutri√ß√£o e gastronomia do Brasil16. Considerou-se suficiente a quantidade entre tr√™s e 10 participantes17.

A t√©cnica Delphi de dois rounds18 foi realizada. Especialistas preencheram question√°rios on-line, com quest√µes semiestruturadas de caracteriza√ß√£o sociodemogr√°fica e de avalia√ß√£o dos itens e dom√≠nios te√≥ricos do instrumento constru√≠dos na fase protot√≠pica. Apontaram melhorias, inclus√£o/exclus√£o de itens, adequa√ß√£o das op√ß√µes da escala do instrumento, e responderam a uma escala Likert de concord√¢ncia (1 = discordo totalmente e 4 = concordo totalmente), para avalia√ß√£o de cada item quanto a:

list-item.p: Clareza: O item foi redigido de forma que o conceito esteja compreens√≠vel e expressa adequadamente o que se espera medir?
Pertin√™ncia: O item reflete os conceitos envolvidos no dom√≠nio e √© adequado para atingir os objetivos propostos?
Relev√¢ncia: O item √© importante para a constru√ß√£o dos dom√≠nios que s√£o o foco da escala de pesquisa?

sec.p: O primeiro round do painel ocorreu entre 26 de mar√ßo e 29 de abril de 2020 e contou com oito especialistas. O grupo de pesquisa examinou os coment√°rios fornecidos, excluiu itens irrelevantes e n√£o pertinentes, realizou adequa√ß√µes daqueles considerados n√£o claros e incluiu itens sugeridos para melhor abrang√™ncia do fen√¥meno. O instrumento foi reapresentado aos especialistas para avalia√ß√£o das reestrutura√ß√µes. O segundo round, iniciado em 28 de maio de 2020, durou 30 dias e contou com sete especialistas.

As caracter√≠sticas dos participantes do estudo foram apresentadas por estat√≠stica descritiva. A raz√£o cr√≠tica de validade de conte√∫do (Critical Content Validity Ratio ‚Äì CVRc) foi utilizada para analisar estatisticamente a validade de cada atributo dos itens e dom√≠nios19e o coeficiente Kappa (k) foi calculado para avaliar a concord√¢ncia entre especialistas sobre cada item20 dos dois rounds do painel. Foram retidos itens com CVRc > 0,0519 e k ‚â• 0,6020. O √≠ndice de validade de conte√∫do (IVC) tamb√©m foi utilizado para analisar a validade do instrumento como um todo21. Resultado > 0,8 foi considerado aceit√°vel22.

A segunda etapa foi a fase de pr√©-teste, em que profissionais de um centro de sa√∫de do munic√≠pio de S√£o Paulo, com caracter√≠sticas similares √† popula√ß√£o de pesquisa do projeto, testaram a usabilidade da EHAPS. Os participantes do pr√©-teste n√£o integraram a amostra de validade de constructo e an√°lise de confiabilidade do instrumento. Eles comentaram sobre poss√≠veis dificuldades de preenchimento do instrumento, clareza e adequa√ß√£o das quest√µes ao objetivo da pesquisa e registraram tempo de resposta.

Na terceira etapa, a validade de constructo e a confiabilidade da EHAPS foram testadas. A escala foi desenvolvida para profissionais envolvidos com a promo√ß√£o da alimenta√ß√£o adequada e saud√°vel de unidades b√°sicas de sa√∫de (UBS) da SMS-SP. H√° 464 UBS no munic√≠pio de S√£o Paulo23.

Integraram a amostra os profissionais que registraram consentimento de sua participa√ß√£o. O recrutamento se deu por contato com coordenadorias regionais de sa√∫de, supervis√µes t√©cnicas de sa√∫de e gestores de UBS para coleta de e-mails de profissionais de interesse. Tamb√©m foi desenvolvido um sitea, divulgado em m√≠dias sociais para apresentar e esclarecer o objetivo da pesquisa e recrutar participantes. O n√∫mero de integrantes da amostra baseou-se nas recomenda√ß√µes de Costello e Osborne24, de 10 sujeitos por item do instrumento.

A coleta de dados teve in√≠cio em 2 de agosto de 2020, com dura√ß√£o de 30 dias. Ao todo, 472 profissionais preencheram um question√°rio sociodemogr√°fico e a EHAPS de forma on-line. Suas caracter√≠sticas foram apresentadas por estat√≠stica descritiva.

Empregou-se an√°lise fatorial explorat√≥ria (AFE) para avaliar a estrutura fatorial da EHAPS. Utilizou-se matriz polic√≥rica e m√©todo de extra√ß√£o Robust Diagonally Weighted Least Squares (RDWLS). A decis√£o sobre o n√∫mero de fatores retidos se deu por an√°lise paralela com permuta√ß√£o aleat√≥ria dos dados observados25 e a rota√ß√£o utilizada foi a Robust Promin26. Valores de 60% da vari√¢ncia total explicada, itens com comunalidade ‚â• 0,4 e cargas fatoriais ‚â• 0,30 foram considerados satisfat√≥rios. Itens com cargas fatoriais cruzadas foram exclu√≠dos27. Valores de KMO ‚â• 0,70 e valores significativos para o √≠ndice Bartlett representaram medidas de adequa√ß√£o da amostra28.

A adequa√ß√£o do modelo foi avaliada por √≠ndices de ajuste Root Mean Square Error of Aproximation (RMSEA), Comparative Fit Index (CFI) e Tucker-Lewis Index (TLI). Valores de RMSEA devem ser < 0,08, e valores de CFI e TLI devem ser > 0,90 ou, preferencialmente, 0,9529,30.

A estabilidade dos fatores foi avaliada pelo √≠ndice H, que avalia qu√£o bem um conjunto de itens representa um fator. Valores de H > 0,80 sugerem uma vari√°vel latente bem definida e provavelmente est√°vel em diferentes estudos31.
Para testar a confiabilidade, calculou-se a fidedignidade composta (FC), com valores aceit√°veis > 0,7032.
Todas as an√°lises estat√≠sticas foram realizadas utilizando o programa estat√≠stico Factor, vers√£o 10.10.0329.

sec.title: RESULTADOS
sec.p: O Quadro detalha os dom√≠nios te√≥ricos e constru√ß√£o de conjunto de itens da vers√£o protot√≠pica da EHAPS com base nas discuss√µes do grupo de pesquisa, explora√ß√£o de referencial te√≥rico e revis√£o sistem√°tica. Foram propostos 44 itens para avaliar as habilidades culin√°rias dom√©sticas de profissionais de sa√∫de da APS, com op√ß√µes de resposta estruturadas em escala tipo Likert de cinco pontos (0 = discordo totalmente e 5 = concordo totalmente).

sec.p: Os instrumentos identificados em revis√£o sistem√°tica apresentavam dimens√µes de planejamento, sele√ß√£o e compra de alimentos e confian√ßa no preparo de alimentos, podendo ou n√£o incluir produtos pr√©-preparados e de conveni√™ncia.

Para a EHAPS, considerou-se como dimens√µes te√≥ricas de HCD para a constru√ß√£o dos itens iniciais o planejamento de compras e do preparo de refei√ß√µes, criatividade culin√°ria, uso de percep√ß√£o sensorial e confian√ßa no preparo de refei√ß√µes baseadas em alimentos in natura, minimamente processados e ingredientes culin√°rios, como preconiza o Guia Alimentar para a Popula√ß√£o Brasileira. As habilidades multitarefas tamb√©m foram identificadas como dom√≠nio te√≥rico, apontadas na literatura cient√≠fica como a capacidade de realizar tarefas simultaneamente no ambiente dom√©stico, representando uma vantagem para o preparo de refei√ß√µes.
A vers√£o protot√≠pica do instrumento foi submetida √† avalia√ß√£o de conte√∫do por especialistas. Os principais resultados do desenvolvimento e valida√ß√£o da EHAPS s√£o apresentados na Figura.

sec.p: Na fase psicom√©trica, a primeira etapa foi a de valida√ß√£o do conte√∫do. O estudo apresentou tamanho amostral adequado para essa etapa. A taxa de resposta para o primeiro round da t√©cnica Delphi foi de 72,7% (8/11) e 87,5% (7/8) para o segundo round. A maioria dos especialistas era do sexo feminino (n = 7; 87,5%), com m√©dia de idade de 42,3 anos (DP = 9,0). Do total, 37,5% (n = 3) eram especialistas (latu sensu), 12,5% (n = 1) mestres, 25% (n = 2) doutores e 12,5% (n = 1) livre docentes. O painel tamb√©m contou com um participante laico (n = 1; 12,5%) com aperfei√ßoamento em cursos livres de gastronomia e 32 horas semanais dedicadas √† culin√°ria. Os especialistas eram docentes em universidades p√∫blicas (25%) e privadas (12,5%), pesquisadores (12,5%), nutricionistas registrados em servi√ßos de alimenta√ß√£o (37,5%) e culinaristas (12,5%). O tempo de experi√™ncia profissional variou de 10 a 33 anos (m√©dia = 17,8 anos; DP = 7,9 anos). O tempo m√©dio dedicado √†s pr√°ticas culin√°rias entre especialistas foi de 12,2 horas semanais (DP = 9,6 horas semanais).

A avalia√ß√£o dos especialistas resultou na exclus√£o de sete itens da vers√£o protot√≠pica do instrumento, dois itens transferidos de dom√≠nio, tr√™s itens revisados quanto √† clareza, seis novos itens propostos e altera√ß√£o da escala de concord√¢ncia para uma escala de frequ√™ncia, totalizando 43 itens v√°lidos quanto ao conte√∫do. Uma vis√£o geral da an√°lise de validade de conte√∫do do instrumento √© demonstrada na Tabela 1.

Esta escala de respostas foi alterada para frequ√™ncia por sugest√£o de especialistas ap√≥s Round 1. Especialistas relataram haver dificuldade, por parte dos respondentes, no que diz respeito √† compreens√£o de escalas de concord√¢ncia. Al√©m disso escalas de concord√¢ncia podem indicar a percep√ß√£o do indiv√≠duo em rela√ß√£o √†s suas habilidades, por√©m n√£o refletem, necessariamente, os comportamentos que possibilitam mensurar, de fato, tais habilidades. Neste caso a adequa√ß√£o para uma escala de frequ√™ncia mostrou ser mais coerente com o objetivo deste instrumento. A altera√ß√£o foi aprovada por especialistas participantes no Round 2. A nova escala √© apresentada a seguir: (1) Nunca, (2) Quase nunca, (3) √Äs vezes, (4) Quase sempre, (5) Sempre. Autores realizaram as altera√ß√µes m√≠nimas aos r√≥tulos e quest√µes do instrumento (sem alterar os objetivos dos mesmos) para torn√°-los coerentes com a nova escala de resposta. O item Comprar alimentos em feiras livres foi exclu√≠do tendo em vista que a aquisi√ß√£o de alimentos pode ser feita em outros locais de compra, n√£o se limitando √†s feiras livres, e que a tem√°tica foi contemplada em outros itens do instrumento; item Fazer o dessalgue r√°pido de carne seca em √°gua fervente exclu√≠do tendo em vista que o prop√≥sito do instrumento √© mensurar as habilidades culin√°rias para o preparo de refei√ß√µes do dia a dia ( o consumo de carne seca n√£o √© realizado cotidianamente no munic√≠pio de S√£o Paulo) e, considerando o r√≥tulo de frequ√™ncia, poderia haver vi√©s de interpreta√ß√£o por parte do respondente (o respondente poderia indicar a frequ√™ncia com que prepara carne seca e n√£o se realiza o dessalgue); item Preparar uma feijoada caseira desde o in√≠cio exclu√≠do tendo em vista que o prop√≥sito do instrumento √© mensurar as habilidades culin√°rias para o preparo de refei√ß√µes do dia a dia (a feijoada, por mais que fa√ßa parte da culin√°ria t√≠pica brasileira, n√£o √© preparada cotidianamente no munic√≠pio de S√£o Paulo) e, considerando o r√≥tulo de frequ√™ncia, poderia ocorrer vi√©s de interpreta√ß√£o por parte do respondente (o respondente poderia indicar a frequ√™ncia com que prepara feijoada e n√£o se a produz do zero).

sec.p: A segunda etapa, de pr√©-teste, contou com a participa√ß√£o de cinco profissionais de um centro de sa√∫de do munic√≠pio de S√£o Paulo. A pandemia por covid-19 representou uma dificuldade para recrutamento, diante da demanda intensificada por atendimentos em UBS. Compuseram a amostra mulheres que atuavam como nutricionistas (n = 3; 60%), psic√≥logas (n = 1; 20%) e enfermeiras (n = 1; 20%). Esta amostra n√£o integrou a an√°lise de validade e confiabilidade do instrumento. Participantes relataram facilidade de acesso ao instrumento pelo computador, compreens√£o das perguntas e op√ß√µes de resposta, com sugest√£o de amplia√ß√£o de fonte das quest√µes, o que foi adotado pelo grupo de pesquisa. O tempo m√©dio de registro de respostas foi de 15 minutos.

Na terceira etapa realizou-se a validade de constructo e a an√°lise de confiabilidade. O estudo apresentou tamanho amostral adequado para essa etapa. A Tabela 2 mostra as caracter√≠sticas dos 472 profissionais de sa√∫de das APS participantes.

sec.p: A AFE foi inicialmente realizada com vers√£o do instrumento validada por especialistas, com 43 itens. Os testes de esfericidade de Bartlett (5.248; gl = 903; p < 0,001) e KMO (0,91: muito bom) sugeriram interpretabilidade da matriz de correla√ß√£o. A an√°lise paralela sugeriu quatro fatores representativos para os dados, com vari√¢ncia explicada de 54,6% e alguns itens apresentaram cargas fatoriais e comunalidades insignificantes25. Ap√≥s exclus√£o desses itens, o instrumento foi novamente analisado. Na sequ√™ncia, itens com cargas fatoriais cruzadas na interpreta√ß√£o de fatores foram removidos e o instrumento foi submetido a nova an√°lise. O modelo reduzido do instrumento manteve 29 dos 43 itens. Os resultados dos testes de esfericidade de Bartlett (5.301,7; gl = 406; p < 0,001) e KMO (0,91: muito bom) sugeriram interpretabilidade da matriz de correla√ß√£o, com quatro fatores identificados na an√°lise paralela e vari√¢ncia explicada de 64,1%.

O modelo final da EHAPS resultou em uma escala do tipo Likert, com op√ß√µes de resposta sobre a frequ√™ncia de a√ß√µes centradas em atributos de HCD, com 29 itensb. O escore da escala √© determinado pela soma das pontua√ß√µes correspondentes √†s op√ß√µes assinaladas em cada item (‚Äúnunca‚Äù = 0, ‚Äúquase nunca‚Äù = 1, ‚Äú√†s vezes‚Äù = 2, ‚Äúquase sempre‚Äù = 3 e ‚Äúsempre‚Äù = 4). A partir da somat√≥ria de pontos dos itens, foram propostas quatro faixas de escore com os seguintes status: HCD baixas (0 a 29 pontos, equivalente √† ‚â§ 25% da pontua√ß√£o m√°xima); HCD moderadamente baixas (30 a 58 pontos, equivalente a > 25% e ‚â§ 50% da pontua√ß√£o m√°xima); HCD moderadamente altas (59 a 87 pontos, correspondente a > 50% e ‚â§ 75% da pontua√ß√£o m√°xima) e HCD altas (88 a 116 pontos, ou > 75% da pontua√ß√£o m√°xima). A interpreta√ß√£o do escore final foi graficamente apresentada em formato de r√©gua com grada√ß√£o de cores (do vermelho intenso, representando HCD baixas, ao verde intenso, representando HCD altas), com mensagens instrucionais sobre o escore atingido e est√≠mulo ao desenvolvimento dessas habilidades.

A Tabela 3 apresenta a sequ√™ncia de redu√ß√£o de itens por meio de AFE. As cargas fatoriais dos itens retidos, √≠ndices de fidedignidade composta e estimativas de replicabilidade dos escores fatoriais (H-index) s√£o observados na Tabela 4. Tamb√©m s√£o reportados nomes e descri√ß√µes do constructo medido por cada fator extra√≠do na AFE com base na interpreta√ß√£o dos itens retidos. Esses fatores foram entendidos como dimens√µes de habilidades culin√°rias dom√©sticas avaliadas pela EHAPS.

sec.title: DISCUSS√ÉO
sec.p: Este estudo reportou o desenvolvimento de um instrumento para mensurar as habilidades culin√°rias dom√©sticas dos profissionais da aten√ß√£o prim√°ria √† sa√∫de do munic√≠pio de S√£o Paulo. A metodologia psicom√©trica revelou-se apropriada para analisar a confiabilidade e validade da EHAPS.

Apesar de ser uma pr√°tica pouco comum em estudos de desenvolvimento de escalas, a etapa de validade de conte√∫do contou com um membro laico na composi√ß√£o do painel de especialistas33. Essa inclus√£o permitiu identificar e corrigir potenciais problemas na escala antecipadamente √† sua aplica√ß√£o para coleta de dados para an√°lise fatorial explorat√≥ria8. A aplica√ß√£o do m√©todo de consenso rigoroso com duas medidas (CVR e k) para quantificar o grau de concord√¢ncia entre especialistas resultou em itens com alta validade de conte√∫do. A opini√£o de especialistas foi considerada em outros estudos que reportaram instrumentos para medir habilidades culin√°rias12,34. No entanto, esses estudos n√£o apresentaram m√©todos emp√≠ricos derivados do julgamento de especialistas como evid√™ncia da validade do conte√∫do. O fato de especialistas opinarem sobre itens do constructo n√£o fornece por si s√≥ informa√ß√µes relevantes para o processo de valida√ß√£o13,28. Assim, este estudo se destaca quanto ao rigor metodol√≥gico empregado para validade de conte√∫do da EHAPS.

Os participantes do pr√©-teste apontaram adequada usabilidade do instrumento. Essa etapa contou com a participa√ß√£o de cinco profissionais de sa√∫de. Rattray et al.35 afirmam que estudos-piloto podem ser realizados usando pequenas amostras, desde que n√£o haja comprometimentos ao desempenho das an√°lises. Considerando que a amostra foi empregada para avaliar qualitativamente a compreens√£o e operacionaliza√ß√£o do instrumento, o n√∫mero de profissionais do pr√©-teste n√£o gerou limita√ß√µes ao estudo.

Em rela√ß√£o √† etapa de avalia√ß√£o do constructo e confiabilidade da EHAPS, a an√°lise paralela sugeriu um instrumento multidimensional com quatro fatores. A multidimensionalidade da escala est√° alinhada com a natureza complexa dos atos de comer e cozinhar, reconhecidos pelo Guia Alimentar para a Popula√ß√£o Brasileira3.

A dimens√£o de planejamento criativo considera a criatividade ao planejar e preparar refei√ß√µes caseiras baseadas em alimentos in natura e minimamente processados e antecipa√ß√£o de procedimentos que facilitem o ato de cozinhar. Achado similar foi observado no estudo de Jomori11, que considera a capacidade criativa de planejar menus e organizar a prepara√ß√£o de refei√ß√µes como habilidades para a pr√°tica culin√°ria centradas no indiv√≠duo. Essa dimens√£o est√° relacionada √† principal recomenda√ß√£o do Guia Alimentar para a Popula√ß√£o Brasileira3: ‚ÄúPrefira sempre alimentos in natura ou minimamente processados e prepara√ß√µes culin√°rias a alimentos ultraprocessados‚Äù, e ao cap√≠tulo sobre a compreens√£o e supera√ß√£o de obst√°culos para colocar essa e outras recomenda√ß√µes em pr√°tica. Antecipar procedimentos culin√°rios possibilita abreviar o tempo de preparo de refei√ß√µes, diante da vida moderna, obst√°culo superado com mais facilidade quando habilidades multitarefas tamb√©m s√£o colocadas em pr√°tica.

A dimens√£o de habilidades multitarefas compreende a capacidade de realizar tarefas dom√©sticas simult√¢neas √†s pr√°ticas culin√°rias. Se o indiv√≠duo for incapaz de cozinhar enquanto lava roupa e cuida dos filhos, poder√° ser menos propenso a preparar uma refei√ß√£o caseira36. Gabe37 discute a influ√™ncia do ambiente dom√©stico sobre qualidade das refei√ß√µes consumidas, destacando discrep√¢ncia de responsabilidades quanto √†s tarefas dom√©sticas relacionadas ao g√™nero, que √© refor√ßada por Mills et al.38 Esses achados oportunizam o emprego da EHAPS em estudos que visem analisar diferen√ßas de habilidades multitarefas entre g√™neros, de modo a estimular o justo compartilhamento de responsabilidades no lar, o que inclui o preparo de refei√ß√µes.

A dimens√£o de confian√ßa quanto √† capacidade culin√°ria corresponde √† autossufici√™ncia para empregar t√©cnicas e utens√≠lios culin√°rios. Segundo Martins12, o julgamento de confian√ßa considera o desempenho individual, que depende da pr√°tica e tarefa executada, considerado um excelente preditor de comportamento para determinar como indiv√≠duos empregam suas habilidades. A EHAPS reduz interpreta√ß√µes err√¥neas sobre as HCD ao desconsiderar quest√µes sobre confian√ßa para preparar refei√ß√µes √† base de produtos pr√©-prontos e de conveni√™ncia, que poderiam superestimar habilidades do indiv√≠duo, problema recorrente em instrumentos internacionais1. A escala de confian√ßa culin√°ria, de Lavelle et al.34, por exemplo, inclui quest√µes sobre confian√ßa para ‚Äúpreparar alimentos em forno micro-ondas, incluindo o aquecimento de pratos prontos‚Äù.

Por fim, a dimens√£o de sele√ß√£o, combina√ß√£o e preparo de alimentos refere-se aos aspectos sensoriais e de quantifica√ß√£o de alimentos visando adequa√ß√£o de compras e procedimentos culin√°rios. Componentes similares, que versam sobre a capacidade de comprar alimentos, utiliz√°-los em prepara√ß√µes e julg√°-los quanto √† qualidade, s√£o encontrados no estudo de Vidgen e Gallegos39 sobre food literacy (letramento em alimentos). Segundo os autores, o baixo letramento em alimentos est√° associado ao aumento de doen√ßas cr√¥nicas relacionadas √† dieta.

Os resultados da an√°lise fatorial explorat√≥ria evidenciaram cargas fatoriais e comunalidades adequadas em todos os itens retidos no instrumento27,28e sugerem uma vari√°vel latente bem definida, com dimens√µes com boa probabilidade de serem est√°veis em estudos futuros31. Os √≠ndices de ajuste apresentados validaram o modelo extra√≠do da an√°lise e confirmam a teoria mensurada, evidenciando constructo bem definido30. A confiabilidade do instrumento tamb√©m se mostrou adequada, com resultados satisfat√≥rios de fidedignidade composta. Essa medida representa um bom indicador para avaliar a qualidade do modelo estrutural do instrumento e √© apresentada como um indicador de precis√£o mais robusto, comparado ao coeficiente alpha32.
Desenvolver instrumentos de avalia√ß√£o √© uma tarefa complexa, sendo apenas incentivada na aus√™ncia de outro instrumento adequado √† realidade investigada40, situa√ß√£o observada neste estudo.

Como vantagem, a EHAPS √© curta, f√°cil de aplicar e padronizada, possibilitando utiliza√ß√£o em estudos comparativos. Este instrumento sintetiza as habilidades culin√°rias dom√©sticas de acordo com faixas de escores de f√°cil interpreta√ß√£o, delimitadas por cores de sem√°foro, fundamentada em diagrama√ß√£o sugerida por Gabe37 para interpreta√ß√£o do escore de seu instrumento de avalia√ß√£o de qualidade da dieta, adotado pelo Minist√©rio da Sa√∫de. Oferece, ainda, mensagens sobre o status das habilidades culin√°rias dom√©sticas do indiv√≠duo, com instru√ß√µes para est√≠mulo e valoriza√ß√£o dessas habilidades. Ressalta-se, por√©m, que a pontua√ß√£o da escala deriva de seu escore bruto. Embora comumente observada em estudos de desenvolvimento de instrumentos, a utiliza√ß√£o desse escore assume uma defini√ß√£o subjetiva de pontos de corte de classifica√ß√£o, conferindo o mesmo peso para itens com diferentes cargas fatoriais. A teoria de resposta ao item √© uma proposta de an√°lise para superar essa limita√ß√£o ao considerar as caracter√≠sticas dos itens do question√°rio quanto √† capacidade de discriminar a vari√°vel de interesse e localiza√ß√£o no respectivo continuum e um modelo probabil√≠stico para calcular e descrever os escores41. Assim, a teoria de resposta ao item poderia ser empregada em estudos futuros, visando aprimorar o escore deste instrumento, validado por m√©todos cl√°ssicos.

A informatiza√ß√£o minimizou poss√≠veis erros do entrevistador. A aplica√ß√£o on-line do instrumento mostrou-se vantajosa devido ao baixo custo e facilidade de acesso. No entanto, sua aplica√ß√£o em papel n√£o foi estudada para averiguar a ocorr√™ncia de resultados semelhantes, o que representa uma limita√ß√£o. A vers√£o impressa viabilizaria acesso aos profissionais de sa√∫de atuantes em locais com internet limitada ou n√£o inclu√≠dos digitalmente.

Outra limita√ß√£o corresponde √† n√£o realiza√ß√£o de estudo de validade convergente. Esse tipo de validade refere-se √†s associa√ß√µes do escore da EHAPS com medidas externas, o que poderia confirmar se a escala mede HCD relacionadas a escolhas alimentares recomendadas pelo Guia Alimentar para a Popula√ß√£o Brasileira e poderia ser performado comparando-se o escore da escala com um recordat√≥rio de 24 horas ou com o escore de uma escala de food literacy. Sua realiza√ß√£o seria oportuna em an√°lises futuras.

Finalmente, a amostra utilizada para an√°lise fatorial explorat√≥ria foi composta por profissionais que atuam na aten√ß√£o prim√°ria do munic√≠pio de S√£o Paulo. Apesar de se consolidar como principal destino das migra√ß√µes regionais no Brasil42, a amostra dessa cidade pode n√£o representar a diversidade cultural da alimenta√ß√£o no territ√≥rio nacional. Desse modo, sugere-se realizar adapta√ß√£o transcultural do instrumento para macrorregi√µes brasileiras.

Este estudo √© inovador no contexto de valoriza√ß√£o da culin√°ria como pr√°tica emancipat√≥ria e de promo√ß√£o de sa√∫de. Compreende-se que a apropria√ß√£o de habilidades culin√°rias dom√©sticas por profissionais da aten√ß√£o prim√°ria permite aproximar seu conhecimento cient√≠fico da vida das pessoas, dos saberes e pr√°ticas sociais, fortalecendo a capacidade dos indiv√≠duos ou comunidades de identificar solu√ß√µes para seu cotidiano. Este instrumento possibilitar√° averiguar fidedignamente a necessidade de qualifica√ß√£o da for√ßa de trabalho para a√ß√µes de promo√ß√£o da alimenta√ß√£o adequada e saud√°vel baseadas em habilidades culin√°rias dom√©sticas. Oportuniza, ainda, identificar necessidades de revis√£o de propostas pedag√≥gicas dos cursos de sa√∫de, para formar profissionais habilitados a atuar pela soberania alimentar e o direito humano √† alimenta√ß√£o adequada em detrimento de pr√°ticas e orienta√ß√µes medicalizadoras.
